WNI Meninggal Saat Urus Paspor di KL, MPR : Harus Jadi Momentum Perbaikan
02 Nov 2019, 19:27 by Bunaiya Fauzi Arubone


WNI Meninggal Saat Urus Paspor di KL, MPR : Harus Jadi Momentum Perbaikan

KBRN, Jakarta : Meninggalnya seorang WNI, Tamam bin Arsyad yang menghembuskan nafas terakhir saat mengantre untuk mengurus paspor di Kedutaan Besar Republik Indonesia (KBRI) Kuala Lumpur (KL), Malaysia pada Kamis 31 Oktober 2019 lalu, harus dijadikan momentum oleh pemerintah untuk melakukan perbaikan secara menyeluruh.Wakil Ketua MPR RI, Hidayat Nur Wahid (HNW) mengucapkan bela sungkawa yang dalam atas meninggalnya pria berusia 55 tahun tersebut. Menurut Anggota DPR Dapil DKI 2 ini, kasus WNI meninggal saat antri Paspor itu harus dijadikan sebagai momentum untuk evaluasi dan perbaikan. "Walaupun penyebabnya karena serangan jantung, namun kenyamanan pelayanan KBRI Kuala Lumpur harus bisa ditingkatkan," ujar Hidayat kepada wartawan di Jakarta, Sabtu (2/11/2019).Terlebih, selama ini untuk mengurus paspor, para pekerja migran biasanya memang harus mengantre panjang. Bahkan tidak jarang pula harus menginap di lokasi karena memang mereka datang dari daerah yang jauh. Hal yang sama juga biasa terjadi di negara lain seperti di Arab Saudi atau Taiwan. Ditekankan Politisi Partai Keadilan Sejahtera (PKS) itu, pada era digital, harusnya semua permasalahan urusan dokumen kewarganegaraan bisa diselesaikan dengan mudah dan cepat oleh pihak kantor perwakilan RI di luar negeri. Namun diingatkannya, sosialisasi terkait digitalisasi penggunaan dokumen pun harus digalakkan."Sehebat apapun sistem yang dibuat namun kurang tersosialisasi dengan baik sama saja hasilnya, harus ada upaya yang lebih masif mengenalkan sistem online. Setiap WNI perlu diedukasi dan dilayani karena tugas negara menlindungi dan mencerdaskan rakyat," jelas Hidayat.Untuk Malaysia, imbuh HNW, dengan jumlah WNI lebih dari 1 juta orang, butuh pelayanan prima dari pihak pemerintah. Kementerian luar negeri pun sebaiknya memperluas akses pelayanan dengan membuka kantor konsulat di beberapa negara bagian dimana banyak pekerja migran yang memperlukan perlindungan. KBRI pun ditegaskan dia sebaiknya memberikan jalur khusus untuk mereka yang sudah termasuk warga senior (60 tahun ke atas), termasuk perempuan dan ibu hamil."Ini merupakan fenomena gunung es dalam pelayanan WNI di luar negeri. Semoga kedepan pemerintah bisa memberikan pelayanan dan perlindungan  terbaik bagi WNI di luar negeri," imbuhnya.Lebih lanjut HNW pun menyoroti tentang keterbatasan ruangan dan kenyamanan di KBRI Kuala lumpur. Kaca mata dia, tempat itu perlu mendapat perhatian khusus dari pemerintah. "Sejak lama kasus-kasus pelayanan bermasalah terus terjadi, inovasi yang dilakukan harus diimbangi dengan edukasi dan sosialisasi yang terus menerus agar inovasi dapat membuahkan hasil maksimal," ketusnya.HNW yang juga Anggota Komisi I DPR RI ini menyatakan, permasalahan WNI menunggu antrean paspor di KBRI Kuala Lumpur bukanlah masalah baru. Hal itu terjadi sejak lama dan terus saja memperburuk citra bangsa."Karena kedutaan tidak mampu menyediakan ruang tunggu yang nyaman, sehingga mereka harus memadati jalanan dan trotoar dan menimbulkan kemacetan akibat tidak berdayanya pemerintah kita menyediakan ruangan yang layak. Bila ingin mengambil paspor sejak  siang saudara kita pahlawan devisa sudah harus mengambil antrian dan menunggu hingga larut malam untuk dapat nomor dan menunggu proses keesokan harinya. Mereka banyak yang datang dari berbagai negara bagian dan ladang atau tempat kerja yang jauh dan terpaksa menunggu di emperan dan trotoar. Bisa dibayangkan sisa tenaga mereka sepulang kerja,  kelelahan, ketidaknyamanan  mengakibatkan mereka mudah terkena penyakit," urainya.Sekali lagi, HNW menegaskan bahwa meninggalnya almarhum Tamam harus dijadikan sebagai momentum dan bahan evaluasi perbaikan ke depan oleh Kemenlu,  imigrasi dan KBRI KL. "Bagaimanya mestinya mekanisme antrian paspor harus dibangun secara lebih manusiawi. Apalagi anggaran Kemlu sangat besar untuk melayani dan melindungi WNI, sementara pahlawan devisa juga memberikan kontribusi remitensi yang besar kepada negara," pungkasnya. (Foto : Antara/ Indrianto Eko Suwarso)

Indonesian citizen died when taking care of passport in KL, MPR: Must be a Momentum for Improvement
02 Nov 2019, 19:27 by Bunaiya Fauzi Arubone


Indonesian citizen died when taking care of passport in KL, MPR: Must be a Momentum for Improvement

KBRN, Jakarta: The death of a citizen, Tamam bin Arsyad who breathed his last while queuing to take care of a passport at the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur (KL), Malaysia on Thursday, October 31, 2019, must be used as a momentum by the government to make repairs thoroughly. Deputy Chairperson of the Indonesian People's Consultative Assembly, Hidayat Nur Wahid (HNW) expressed his deepest condolences for the death of the 55-year-old man. According to this DPR member of DKI 2 Electoral District, the case of Indonesian citizen who died while queuing up for the passport should be used as a momentum for evaluation and improvement. "Even though the cause is due to a heart attack, the convenience of the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur services must be improved," Hidayat told reporters in Jakarta, Saturday (11/02/2019). Moreover, all this time to arrange passports, migrant workers usually do have to queue long . In fact, not infrequently also have to stay at the location because they come from far areas. The same thing is common in other countries such as Saudi Arabia or Taiwan. The Prosperous Justice Party (PKS) Politician stressed, in the digital era, all issues of citizenship document matters should be resolved easily and quickly by the Indonesian representative offices abroad. But he reminded, the socialization related to digitizing the use of documents must be encouraged. "No matter how great the system is made but not well socialized with the same results, there must be a more massive effort to introduce the online system. Every citizen needs to be educated and served because the duty of the state is to protect and educate the people. "Hidayat explained. For Malaysia, added HNW, with more than 1 million Indonesian citizens, need excellent service from the government. The foreign ministry should also expand access to services by opening consular offices in several states where many migrant workers need protection. The Indonesian Embassy also emphasized that he should provide a special path for those who have included senior citizens (60 years and over), including women and pregnant women. for Indonesian citizens abroad, "he added. Furthermore HNW also highlighted the limitations of space and comfort at the Indonesian Embassy in Kuala lumpur. In his eyes, that place needs special attention from the government. "For a long time problematic service cases have continued to occur, innovations carried out must be balanced with continuous education and outreach so that innovation can produce maximum results," he said. HNW, who is also a Member of the House of Representatives Commission I, stated that Indonesian citizens were waiting for passport queues at The Indonesian Embassy in Kuala Lumpur is not a new problem. It happened a long time ago and continues to worsen the image of the nation. "Because the embassy is unable to provide a comfortable waiting room, so they have to crowded the streets and sidewalks and cause congestion due to the powerlessness of our government to provide a decent room. If you want to take a passport since noon you brother we foreign exchange heroes have to take a queue and wait until late at night to get a number and wait for the process the next day, many of whom come from various states and fields or workplaces far away and are forced to wait on pavements and sidewalks. work, fatigue, inconvenience cause them to be susceptible to disease, "he explained. Once again, HNW stressed that the death of the late Tamam should be used as a momentum and evaluation material for future improvement by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, immigration and the Indonesian Embassy in KL. "As for the passport queue mechanism, it must be developed more humanely. Moreover, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs' budget is very large to serve and protect Indonesian citizens, while foreign exchange heroes also contribute a large remittance to the country," he concluded.
